title: Money & Values
description: Assess how your deeper values connect to money

questions.text: I feel my partner understands what money means to me emotionally.

therapeutic.rationale: Money carries emotional weight—security, freedom, status, love. When your partner understands your emotional relationship with money, they can better support you.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel understood, share your money story—what you learned growing up, what money represents to you.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual understanding of each other's emotional relationship with money creates deeper connection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What does money mean to you beyond paying bills? Does your partner know this?

questions.text: I believe our financial choices reflect values I'm proud of.

therapeutic.rationale: Financial choices that align with your values feel good; those that don't create cognitive dissonance. Pride in your financial choices indicates values alignment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner isn't proud of financial choices, explore what feels out of alignment. What values aren't being honored?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared pride in financial choices reflects shared values being lived out.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What financial choices make you proud? Which ones feel inconsistent with your values?

questions.text: I feel my partner's money background helps me understand them better.

therapeutic.rationale: Understanding your partner's financial background—how they grew up, what they learned about money—creates compassion for their financial behaviors and beliefs.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel their background is understood or relevant, more sharing is needed. Money behaviors often make sense in context.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual understanding of financial backgrounds creates empathy in financial matters.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What did you learn about money growing up? How does it affect you now?

questions.text: I believe we share similar beliefs about what money is for.

therapeutic.rationale: Core beliefs about money's purpose—security, experiences, freedom, helping others—shape all financial decisions. Aligned beliefs create natural partnership.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different beliefs about money's purpose need discussion. Neither is wrong, but understanding each other's 'why' builds bridges.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared beliefs about money's purpose create a unified approach to financial life.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What is money for, in your view? How does your partner see it?

questions.text: I feel our approach to money supports what matters most to us.

therapeutic.rationale: When your financial approach supports your deepest values—family, experiences, security, growth—money becomes a tool for what matters rather than a source of stress.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel your approach supports what matters, explore the gap. What values feel unsupported financially?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sense that your approach supports what matters creates purpose in your financial life.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What matters most to you that money can help support? Is your current approach doing that?
